title: Access Control
description: Advanced access control for Controlled Unclassified Information (CUI)

questions.question: Do you limit system access to only authorized users?
questions.context: This means having a list of who should have access to systems with CUI, and ensuring only those people can get in.
questions.examples: User accounts, Active Directory, access request process
questions.followUp: Who manages user accounts? How do you add/remove users?
assessmentObjectives: System access is limited to authorized users
System access is limited to processes acting on behalf of authorized users
System access is limited to authorized devices

questions.question: Do you limit what authorized users can do based on their job role?
questions.context: Not everyone needs admin access. Accounting shouldn't access IT systems, IT shouldn't access HR files.
questions.examples: Admin vs regular user accounts, role-based permissions
questions.followUp: Do you have different permission levels? Who has admin access?

questions.question: Do you control the flow of CUI within and between systems?
questions.context: Information flow control determines where CUI can travel, not just who can access it.
questions.examples: Network segmentation, data loss prevention, firewall rules between systems
questions.followUp: How do you prevent CUI from moving to unauthorized systems?
assessmentObjectives: Information flows are identified and documented
Approved authorizations for information flow exist

questions.question: Do you separate duties to prevent single person from causing harm?
questions.context: Critical functions should require multiple people. One person shouldn't be able to create and approve.
questions.examples: Separate admin roles, dual approval for changes, segregation of duties matrix
questions.followUp: What critical functions require multiple people? How is this enforced?
assessmentObjectives: Access authorizations support separation of duties
Separation is enforced technically or procedurally

questions.question: Do you implement least privilege and restrict admin functions?
questions.context: Users only get minimum access needed for their job. Admin access is strictly controlled.
questions.examples: Regular vs admin accounts, just-in-time access, privileged access management
questions.followUp: How do you determine minimum necessary access? Who can perform admin functions?
assessmentObjectives: Security functions are identified and restricted
Privileged accounts are minimized and controlled

questions.question: Do privileged users use non-privileged accounts for regular work?
questions.context: Admins shouldn't use their admin account for email and web browsing.
questions.examples: Separate admin accounts, UAC prompts, sudo requirements
questions.followUp: Do admins have separate accounts? When do they use privileged accounts?
assessmentObjectives: Non-privileged accounts are used for non-admin tasks

questions.question: Do you prevent and log when non-privileged users try admin functions?
questions.context: Regular users shouldn't be able to run admin commands, and attempts should be logged.
questions.examples: UAC controls, sudo restrictions, audit logs of privilege escalation attempts
questions.followUp: What happens when a regular user tries to do something administrative?
assessmentObjectives: Non-privileged users cannot execute privileged functions
Attempts to execute privileged functions are captured in logs
Logs are reviewed for unauthorized attempts

questions.question: Do you limit unsuccessful login attempts?
questions.context: After several failed logins, accounts should lock to prevent password guessing.
questions.examples: Account lockout after 5 attempts, 30-minute lockout period
questions.followUp: How many failed attempts trigger lockout? How long is the lockout?
assessmentObjectives: Limit on consecutive failed attempts is defined

questions.question: Do you display privacy and security notices at login?
questions.context: Login banners warn about authorized use only and monitoring.
questions.examples: Windows login banner, SSH banner, web application notices
questions.followUp: What does your login banner say? Is it on all systems?
assessmentObjectives: Notice is consistent with CUI requirements

questions.question: Do sessions lock after inactivity?
questions.context: Computers should lock automatically when not in use.
questions.examples: 15-minute screen lock, password required to unlock
questions.followUp: How long before screens lock? Do users lock screens manually?

questions.question: Do you automatically terminate sessions after inactivity?
questions.context: Sessions should end after extended inactivity, not just lock.
questions.examples: VPN disconnects after 2 hours idle, RDP sessions timeout
questions.followUp: When do remote sessions terminate? What about local sessions?
assessmentObjectives: Different timeouts for different session types

questions.question: Do you monitor and control remote access?
questions.context: VPN, remote desktop, and other remote connections need extra monitoring.
questions.examples: VPN logs, authorized remote access methods, remote session monitoring
questions.followUp: What remote access methods are allowed? How are they monitored?

questions.question: Do you use encryption for remote sessions?
questions.context: Remote connections must be encrypted to protect CUI in transit.
questions.examples: VPN with AES encryption, SSH instead of Telnet, HTTPS not HTTP
questions.followUp: What encryption is used for remote access? Any unencrypted protocols?

questions.question: Do you control and monitor privileged remote access?
questions.context: Admin access from outside needs extra scrutiny and control.
questions.examples: Jump boxes, privileged access management, session recording
questions.followUp: Can admins connect directly from home? How is admin remote access different?
assessmentObjectives: Additional controls for privileged access exist

questions.question: Do you route remote access through managed points?
questions.context: All remote connections should go through controlled entry points.
questions.examples: VPN gateway, remote access gateway, bastion hosts
questions.followUp: Can users connect directly to internal systems? What are the entry points?
assessmentObjectives: All remote access goes through these points

questions.question: Do you control wireless access with authentication and encryption?
questions.context: WiFi needs strong security - WPA2/WPA3 with enterprise authentication.
questions.examples: WPA2-Enterprise, certificate-based WiFi, no open networks
questions.followUp: What WiFi security is used? Any guest networks? How do they connect to CUI systems?

questions.question: Do you protect wireless access using authentication and encryption?
questions.context: Wireless connections must authenticate users and encrypt traffic.
questions.examples: 802.1X authentication, AES encryption, no WEP or WPA
questions.followUp: What authentication method for WiFi? What encryption standard?

questions.question: Do you control mobile device connections?
questions.context: Phones, tablets, and laptops need special controls when accessing CUI.
questions.examples: MDM solution, mobile device policy, BYOD restrictions
questions.followUp: Can personal phones access email? What about company laptops at home?

questions.question: Do you encrypt CUI on mobile devices?
questions.context: Laptops, phones, tablets must encrypt CUI storage.
questions.examples: BitLocker, FileVault, iOS/Android encryption
questions.followUp: Are all laptops encrypted? What about phones with email?
assessmentObjectives: Encryption is enabled on mobile devices

questions.question: Do you control connections from external systems?
questions.context: This includes VPNs, remote desktop, and any external access to your network.
questions.examples: VPN with authentication, firewall rules, remote access policy
questions.followUp: How do employees connect remotely? What about contractors?

questions.question: Do you limit use of portable storage on external systems?
questions.context: USB drives with CUI shouldn't be used on non-company computers.
questions.examples: Encrypted USB only, no personal computer use, policy enforcement
questions.followUp: Can employees use USB drives at home? What about at client sites?

questions.question: Do you control what employees can post publicly about federal contracts?
questions.context: FCI shouldn't be shared on social media, public websites, or in marketing materials.
questions.examples: Social media policy, training on information handling
questions.followUp: Do you have a social media policy? Who reviews public posts?
